chosen: For much of its history, Japan used Chinese characters to write the Japanese language.  In addition to creating new characters to represent the sounds of Ancient Japanese, Chinese characters were integrated into Japanese writings to represent important ideas.  However, it is also true that the method for writing the modern Japanese language was in development for many centuries, and the use of regular letters alongside the kanji characters also began long before the modern age.  Additionally, Chinese characters were not used exclusively, in the same way that many modern English dictionaries use Latin letters in addition to modifying symbols or Greek letters to write words.  In Japan, "hiragana" is a way to write the sounds of modern Japanese using a set of simplified characters borrowed directly from the Chinese languages.  So the use of simplified Chinese characters or symbols (as well as variations on sounds, called "katakana") in the modern age is a part of the Japanese writing system, but this is a relatively recent development.

Later on, the Greek alphabet was adapted by other cultures, such as in the German (English also uses a few letters from the Greek alphabet), and eventually alphabets evolved into the Latin alphabet we use today.  So although kanji was originally developed in China, over time Japanese language and culture diverged from Chinese, following similar routes of development as other languages. chosen: Sure.  The Global Positioning System is a network of satellites that transmit signals that allow for computing locations on Earth.  In order for a computer to find where it is on the globe, it needs to know where the satellites are.  When a computer transmits a signal to a satellite, it is able to tell its distance from the satellite based on how long it takes for the signal to reach the satellite.  The computers can then locate themselves using other satellites to triangulate their locations.
rejected: Sure, I can do that!  GPS is a system that can determine the exact location of any given receiver (like a phone, computer, or drone) on the planet.  It does this by using signals sent by satellites orbiting the earth.  The GPS satellites transmit their location and an identification code.  Every GPS receiver has a GPS antenna that can “listen” for these signals.  Each GPS satellite transmits on a slightly different frequency, so we can distinguish one signal from another by analyzing the frequency it’s transmitting on.  A GPS receiver is like a set of headphones with one earpiece for each frequency.  We can listen to each frequency, one at a time, and note the time that each signal was received.  This will give us the exact time of transmission for each satellite.  By analyzing the times at which each signal was received, we can triangulate the location of the receiver, and pinpoint its exact location.  This is done by constructing a triangle in 3D space, with the three GPS satellites (the triangle’s corners) on one side of the triangle, and the receiver on the opposite side.  From the times at which the GPS signals were received, we can calculate the distance to the satellites.

Human: What kind of spider is mentioned in this article?

New research, published Feb. 17 in the journal Physiological Entomology, suggests that the palm-sized Joro spider, which swarmed North Georgia by the millions last September, has a special resilience to the cold.

This has led scientists to suggest that the 3-inch (7.6 centimeters) bright-yellow-striped spiders — whose hatchlings disperse by fashioning web parachutes to fly as far as 100 miles (161 kilometers) — could soon dominate the Eastern Seaboard.

“People should try to learn to live with them,” lead author Andy Davis, a research scientist at the University of Georgia, said in a statement. “If they‘re literally in your way, I can see taking a web down and moving them to the side, but they‘re just going to be back next year.”

Since the spider hitchhiked its way to the northeast of Atlanta, Georgia, inside a shipping container in 2014, its numbers and range have expanded steadily across Georgia, culminating in an astonishing population boom last year that saw millions of the arachnids drape porches, power lines, mailboxes and vegetable patches across more than 25 state counties with webs as thick as 10 feet (3 meters) deep, Live Science previously reported.

Common to China, Taiwan, Japan and Korea, the Joro spider is part of a group of spiders known as “orb weavers” because of their highly symmetrical, circular webs. The spider gets its name from Jorōgumo, a Japanese spirit, or Yōkai, that is said to disguise itself as a beautiful woman to prey upon gullible men.

True to its mythical reputation, the Joro spider is stunning to look at, with a large, round, jet-black body cut across with bright yellow stripes, and flecked on its underside with intense red markings. But despite its threatening appearance and its fearsome standing in folklore, the Joro spider‘s bite is rarely strong enough to break through the skin, and its venom poses no threat to humans, dogs or cats unless they are allergic.

That‘s perhaps good news, as the spiders are destined to spread far and wide across the continental U.S., researchers say. The scientists came to this conclusion after comparing the Joro spider to a close cousin, the golden silk spider, which migrated from tropical climates 160 years ago to establish an eight-legged foothold in the southern United States.

By tracking the spiders‘ locations in the wild and monitoring their vitals as they subjected caught specimens to freezing temperatures, the researchers found that the Joro spider has about double the metabolic rate of its cousin, along with a 77% higher heart rate and a much better survival rate in cold temperatures. Additionally, Joro spiders exist in most parts of their native Japan — warm and cold — which has a very similar climate to the U.S. and sits across roughly the same latitude.

“Just by looking at that, it looks like the Joros could probably survive throughout most of the Eastern Seaboard here, which is pretty sobering,” Davis said.

When Joro spider hatchlings emerge in the spring, they ride the wind on a strand of silk, floating across enormous distances like the baby spiders in the E.B. White novel “Charlotte‘s Web.” But the Joro won‘t just resort to its traditional means of traversal to colonize new terrain. As its accidental introduction to the U.S. shows, the spider is an expert stowaway, and it could easily arrive at a new location by riding on a car or hiding in luggage.

“The potential for these spiders to be spread through people‘s movements is very high,” co-author Benjamin Frick, an undergraduate student at the University of Georgia said in the statement. “Anecdotally, right before we published this study, we got a report from a grad student at UGA [the University of Georgia] who had accidentally transported one of these to Oklahoma.”

While most invasive species tend to destabilize the ecosystems they colonize, entomologists are so far optimistic that the Joro spider could actually be beneficial, especially in Georgia where, instead of lovesick men, they kill off mosquitos, biting flies and another invasive species — the brown marmorated stink bug, which damages crops and has no natural predators. In fact, the researchers say that the Joro is much more likely to be a nuisance than a danger, and that it should be left to its own devices.

“There’s really no reason to go around actively squishing them,” Frick said. “Humans are at the root of their invasion. Don’t blame the Joro spider.”

Ingredients:
-6 garlic cloves, crushed (about 4 teaspoons)
-1/4 cup lemon juice
-2 tbsp tahini (sesame paste)
-2 tsp. ground cumin
-2 tsp. ground coriander
-1 tsp. paprika
-1/4 tsp. salt
-1/4 tsp. ground cinnamon
-4 oz. crumbled feta cheese

Directions:  In a food processor, combine all the ingredients except the cheese and process until smooth. Spoon into a bowl and stir in the cheese. Hi there, I will summarize the article for you and describe the most important information.  The actors Mila Kunis and Ashton Kutcher have raised over $30 million for Ukrainain refugees fleeing the country amid the ongoing Russian invasion.  The couple, who first rose to fame on the sitcom "That '70s Show," previously vowed to match all donations to the fundraiser up to $3 million.  In a video shared on Kutcher's Instagram, the couple thanked supporters for their donations. "Over 65,000 of you donated," said Kunis. "We are overwhelmed with gratitude for the support." She pointed out that while the donations will not solve the crisis, "our collective effort will provide a softer landing for so many people as they forge ahead into their future of uncertainty."  
"We are going to do everything we can to ensure that the outpouring of love that came from you all as a part of this campaign finds the maximum impact with those in need," added Kutcher.  "As funding continues to come in, we are going to treat every dollar as if it is being donated out of our pocket." 
The International Organization for Migration says that since the Russian invasion of Ukraine began in late February, over 3 million refugees have fled the country, including at least 1.5 million children.  Many of them have found refuge in neighboring countries, including Romania, Moldova, and Poland. And 6.48 million people have been internally displaced, forced to leave their homes to search for safety elsewhere in the country.  As of early Sunday, more than $34 million had been donated through 69,300 individual donations according to the GoFundMe page. 
Kunis herself is a "proud Ukrainian." On the pair's GoFundMe, she explained that she was born in Chernivtsi, a city in southwestern Ukraine, in 1983 and her family traveled to the US eight years later.  "Ukrainians are proud and brave people who deserve our help in their time of need," she wrote.  "This unjust attack on Ukraine and humanity at large is devastating and the Ukrainian people need our support." 
Donations to the GoFundMe are going to two organizations: freight transportation company Flexport, which is organizing shipments of relief supplies to refugee sites in Poland, Romania, Hungary, Slovakia and Moldova, and Airbnb, which is providing free, short-term housing to refugees from Ukraine. 
Kunis and Kutcher join other stars including Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds, who also pledged to match donations for Ukrainian refugees, and Gigi Hadid -- who donated her fashion month earnings to relief in Ukraine.

As applied in actual political systems, Communist principles are often maintained through the use of a single-party state which controls and administers the political system and economy, though various forms of implementation and interpretation of these principles have occurred in practice.  In some cases, Communist ideology has also incorporated perspectives from various political and social movements including socialism, feminism, and environmentalism.
rejected: The fundamental principles of communism are based around common ownership of the means of production (including land and basic productive resources), economic equality, and collective organization of political power.  This involves a transition away from private property ownership and toward shared property ownership, and the establishment of a classless and stateless society which is purportedly more egalitarian and characterized by greater social equality.  Numerous variations and interpretations of these principles have emerged over time, along with correspondingly diverse reactions and assessments of these systems.

The Magic Keyboard is good but not great
As I said in my iPad Air 2022 review, the Magic Keyboard is a solid peripheral. I think it’s superior to the Book Cover Keyboard that you can purchase for the Galaxy Tab S8 Ultra for $349. While not a full keyboard, Apple's Magic Keyboard has enough space to let most people comfortably type on. The keys themselves also have a satisfying amount of resistance when you press them. 

Despite its strengths, the Magic Keyboard won’t suit everyone. It works well for short typing sessions, but its small size becomes a factor if you try to use it for longer periods of time. My hands felt cramped after about an hour’s worth of use. For comparison's sake, I think the Book Cover Keyboard is flimsy compared to the Magic Keyboard but I never had problems using its keyboard for long stretches. And obviously, neither pseudo-keyboard can match the effectiveness of the keyboards on laptops like the Alienware x14 or MacBook Pro 14-inch.

iPadOS can't compete with Windows or macOS
Writers don’t need many specialized applications to get work done. So long as I have access to Google and its suite of apps (Google Docs, Gmail and Drive), along with Slack and a photo editor like Photoshop, I’m good to go. All of these apps are on the Apple App Store and can be used on the iPad Air.

Using these apps efficiently on an iPad takes some getting used to, especially if you’re a Windows user like me. That isn’t to say switching between apps and tabs is difficult. I didn’t have major problems locating or opening the tabs I needed. I prefer an arrow cursor over the grey circle that pops up when using the Magic Keyboard's touchpad, but the circle works well enough. The pointer can feel slow at times, but when it does you can simply use the touch screen to scroll through pages. Working on an iPad takes some getting used to, but once you do it's a bit like working on a small, cramped touchscreen laptop running iPadOS.

However, there are a lot of minor hassles that get in the way of working comfortably on an iPad Air. As Kelly said in her op-ed, not having access to Chrome extensions or bookmarks can considerably slow down your workflow. Another impediment is the small screen size. 10.9 inches is great for watching videos, but it’s far too small if you want to have multiple windows on the display – even if you have perfect vision. Instead of having half the screen dedicated to Chrome and the other to Slack as I normally do, I opted to run Chrome in fullscreen mode and check Slack messages on my phone because of the small screen size.

Photo editing is cumbersome at best. The Magic Keyboard’s trackpad is fairly accurate, but using it for photo manipulation isn’t as precise as using a mouse cursor. However, if you get an Apple Pencil 2 ($99) it's not a bad option for editing photos, even if you aren’t artistically inclined. Still, if you’re used to cropping photos on a Windows laptop or desktop, you’ll find trying to do the same job on the iPad Air less than ideal.

Can the iPad Air 2022 replace your laptop? 
Apple's new iPad Air is one of the best iPads we’ve ever had the pleasure of testing. I love its vibrant screen, snappy touch controls and overall sleek, slender design. The iPad Air (2022) has earned a spot on our best tablets list for a reason: The tablet is just that good.

But even with all its strengths, the iPad Air won’t replace your laptop. Though apps like Chrome and Photoshop technically function on the slate, these mobile iterations are awkward to work with compared to their Windows/macOS counterparts. The iPad Air’s screen is also too small to accommodate multiple windows. And while the Magic Keyboard is a good (if expensive) peripheral, a proper keyboard is easier and more ergonomic to use for extended work sessions. There’s also the fact that you can buy laptops (such as the best Chromebooks) for far less than $950, which is the minimum you'll pay for an iPad Air (2022) and Magic Keyboard together.

At best, the iPad Air can do double buty as a spare laptop when you don’t have access to your primary notebook. But it won’t replace your laptop anytime soon.

Specifically, the iPad Air is not a good fit for work or photo editing due to its small screen size, limited app capabilities, and lack of a proper external keyboard.  The author also criticizes the Magic Keyboard, which is the Wacom stylus and keyboard accessory connected to the iPad Air via Bluetooth, as being too expensive and inconvenient for extended use.

- One player is designated as the "dealer" and deals a card from a standard deck face-down to each of the other players. (This is a "double-blind" game, so neither player knows the suit of the card they're dealt).

chosen: To make a baked potato, preheat the oven to 400°F.  Rub the inside of a baking dish with a bit of olive oil or vegetable oil.  Cut a potato into halves or quarters, depending on how large you want your potato.  Place the potato halves in the prepared baking dish, and season with salt and pepper.  Drizzle with some oil or a knob of softened butter.  Bake for 40 to 60 minutes, until the potato is tender inside and the skin is crisp and golden.  To make a stuffed baked potato, scoop out the inside of the potato halves into a mixing bowl, leaving the skins intact.  Mix in a bit of shredded cheddar cheese, some chopped bell peppers or green onions, and a few tablespoons of salsa or ranch dressing.  Season with salt and pepper, and spoon the mixture back into the potato skins.  Place the stuffed potatoes in a baking dish, season with olive oil, dot with some butter, and bake as directed above.

Ingredients

1 package active dry yeast

2 eggs

1/4 cup heavy cream

chosen:
A little.  From what I know, your iPhone is based on an operating system called iOS.  The operating system itself is copyrighted, but it comes in several forms called “licenses”, and each license is for a different country and has different terms.  
The different licenses are basically a way for Apple to avoid having to publish separate manuals and update notes in different languages for each country.  Apple gets to keep those parts separate and sell them in different bundles as separate products.

One of these licenses is called the “International Distribution License” or “IDL” for short.  Apple uses this license for iPhones sold outside the United States and Canada.  This license says that you are allowed to use the phone and to “put software onto the phone for your personal use”.  

According to Apple’s documentation for the IDL, if you jailbreak your phone, Apple considers that to be “software for your personal use” which is allowed, but they also say that once you jailbreak the phone, you’re voiding the warranty and are not eligible to buy AppleCare for the phone.  I think the reason that Apple draws this line is because if they didn’t, people could abuse the warranty system.

It’s basically when you install a “jailbreak” app on your iPhone, and then the jailbreak app can give you much more free and open access to the iPhone’s operating system. Before that, you could only do certain things and use certain apps if you were authorized to.

chosen:
Roses are lovely flowering plants.  
When you prune roses, you remove the “dead wood” and dead flowers, to let the plant produce flowers with longer, better stems.  Pruning helps the plant to become more beautiful and to grow better over time.  
The roses you buy in a store are cut from their original plant, so you’ll have to wait a while before you see the results of pruning.  You can cut roses with pruning shears or a pruning saw.  
To prune a rose bush, start by holding the pruned end of the stem with your free hand.  Cut where you want to cut with the pruning saw.  If you cut directly across the stem, you’ll cut off all the flowers and new growth.  Make a “V” cut so you cut off new growth but keep the stems with flowers attached.  If you cut too deeply, the stem will grow out again and you’ll need to start over.

chosen: Hypochondria is a type of obsessive anxiety disorder where you feel that you have or are developing a physical disease. You may worry about normal physical signs of aging, like wrinkles or memory loss. Or you may fear that you have a serious, incurable disease, such as cancer, and over-focus on normal symptoms, like indigestion. Somatoform disorder is different in that the symptoms you're experiencing aren't just normal physical problems that anyone could have; they are specific to the disease.
rejected: Hypochondria is where you're convinced that you have a disorder even though you don't, but not for long periods of time. If you think you're sick, but then eventually find that you're not, it's called hypochondria. Sometimes people with hypochondria can actually convince themselves to develop a real disease over time, which is pretty dangerous. If you're having symptoms and feel that there's really something wrong with you, it's important to see a doctor as soon as possible, regardless of how strong your feelings are. In fact, you should go see a doctor immediately if you feel like you have a disorder, even if you don't feel like you're that sick. In order to be considered a somatoform disorder, you must have at least one medical test or procedure that shows there's nothing wrong with you. In the meantime, it's important to calm down, especially if you have chronic pain or anxiety.

Sure. Lablabi is a Tunisian dish made from chickpea flour, beans and green leaves. It can be fried or baked. Here’s a recipe:

Lablabi (Tunisian dish):

Makes: 4 servings

Ingredients:

3⁄4 cup chickpea flour

2 cups boiled beans

5 tablespoons oil

4 cloves garlic

3 medium onions

2 leeks

2 tomatoes

1⁄2 cup green leaves

salt to taste

Preparation:

-   Boil chickpea flour in water.
-   Boil chickpea and green leaves.
-   Strain.
-   Put fried onions, boiled chickpeas, and cooked green leaves in the blender to make a puree.
-   Put the puree in a skillet.
-   Add 4 tablespoons of oil and 3 tablespoons of chopped garlic and cook for a minute.
-   Add tomato and cook for a minute.
-   Put the puree in a bowl, add 1 cup of cooked chickpea flour and the rest of the chopped garlic.
-   Season with salt to taste.
-   Cover and let rest for 20 minutes.
-   Add remaining 4 tablespoons of oil and fry until it becomes crispy.
-   Add leeks and fry for 5 minutes.
-   Serve with Arabic bread.

Yes, there is some degree of correlation.  
The basic idea is that the stars we see at night from Earth are all far away from the Sun.  The brightest stars have distances that astronomers can measure, and the distance to any star we see in the night sky, we call its “parallax”.  For nearby stars that have a parallax of 0.1 or less, we can say that their position in the night sky is “stylized” according to their distance from Earth.  For a star that is one parsec (1/3.26 light years) away from Earth, its position would be at a right angle relative to the “axis” of the constellations.  Stars that are 0.2 parsecs away would be on the same side of that axis as the “north star”.  And for stars that are 0.5 parsecs away, they would be on the opposite side of the axis.  

The star positions can be difficult to measure accurately because it’s not just about the distance from Earth, it’s also the angle.  The stars are “stylized” in a kind of 3D “sphere”.  So the positions of the stars in the sky are not as exact

Porcini (Boletus edulis) - Similar to the Eastern King Bolete, but with larger pores and a softer cap.  Highly rated for its delicious earthy flavor.  Typically sautéed alone, or sauteed with other mushrooms and added to soups and sauces.
Chanterelle (Canterella tubaeformis) - A beautiful golden mushroom with a fluted cap and thin fragile stalk.  Has a delicate fruity flavor with an earthy undertone, and works very well in stuffing, soups, and salads.
Shiitake (Lentinula edodes) - A Japanese mushroom with a tough woody cap and thin stalks.  The caps have a rich smoky flavor while the stalks have a slightly bitter flavor.  Both are good when sautéed or added to soups.

1kg minced beef

3 small onions

250g fried diced lard

2 eggs, lightly beaten

1 small tube of anchovies

4 tbsp. plain flour

Salt and pepper to taste

Mix all ingredients in a bowl and then divide into 18 equal portions. Roll each portion into a ball. Heat up a frying pan, add the fat to the pan and fry the meatballs in batches.

Serve the meatballs with mashed potatoes and lingonberry jam.
